settings.title: What is psoriasis?
settings.text: Psoriasis is an autoimmune skin condition that speeds up the skin production process. This rapid build-up of skin cells can show up as scales that range in colour depending on your skin tone. The scales are most commonly found on the elbow and knee joints, however, can also develop on many other areas of the body.

settings.title: How is psoriasis treated?
settings.text: Although psoriasis has no current cure, there are ways of treating it that can reduce inflammation and slow down the growth of skin cells. The topical solutions are directly applied to the affected skin and may contain a corticosteroid, retinoid or anthralin. Oral or injected medications can also be prescribed for those with moderate to severe psoriasis.

settings.title: prevalence of psoriasis in the UK
settings.text: According to NICE, the prevalence of psoriasis is estimated to be around 1.3% to 2.2% in the UK.

settings.title: of people with psoriasis have plaque psoriasis
settings.text: According to NICE, the red, scaly plaques that vary in extent are the most common form of psoriasis.

settings.title: What causes psoriasis to start?
settings.text:
It's not known exactly what causes psoriasis to start but it is thought to be a problem with the immune system. The t-cells that normally fight against bacteria start to attack the skin cells. Genetics is also a factor as well as several triggers including:

An injury to the skin

Excess alcohol consumption

Smoking

Stress

Hormonal changes

Certain medications

Throat infections

Other immune disorders, such as HIV.

settings.title: Is psoriasis an illness or disease?
settings.text: Psoriasis is a long-lasting chronic disease.

settings.title: How can I treat psoriasis on my scalp?
settings.text: Scalp psoriasis can be treated with products that have salicylic acid or tar (either coal or wood tar). These products are available over the counter.

settings.title: Is psoriasis contagious?
settings.text: Psoriasis is not contagious.
